2.text:
Chairman Kovner, President Polisi, distinguished fellow
honorees and guests, esteemed faculty,

10.text:
friends, family members, and finally, accomplished,
ecstatic Juilliard graduates of the Class

18.text:
of 2016. Let me start, dear grads, by uttering
some words you should get used to: "Bravo,

34.text:
Brava, BRAVI! Well done!" I want you all to
take in the joyful vibration at Alice Tully

43.text:
this morning -- it may be the last time you
are in a room full of this many performing

48.text:
artists, ALL of whom are feeling perfectly
happy and fulfilled. I am so deeply grateful,

61.text:
honored, and moved, as well as giddy with
excitement, to be here at this year's commencement

69.text: ceremony. When President Polisi asked if I would speak today, I told him I'd be much too

74.text:
intimidated to address an audience of brilliant
students on such a momentous occasion. But

80.text:
he simply said, "You attended the school.
You have something in common." Well yes, indeed,

88.text: my fellow alums. I began my studies at the Drama Division in the autumn of -- Good Heavens! --

96.text: 1970! The building was brand new and the elevator still had the new car smell. At the

104.text:
time, the entrance was on 66th street, and as
you walked into the lobby, there was a long

109.text:
simple desk behind which sat a heavyset woman
named Nora who in a thick Irish brogue greeted

116.text:
us all by our first name and was always up
for a chat. I confess I can't quite get used

123.text:
to the entrance on 65th, the stern-faced security
guard, the turnstile, and then that staircase

138.text:
that reminds me of a Mayan temple at Chichen
Itza. But honestly -- it doesn't matter which

148.text:
entrance you use, as long as you GET INTO
JULLIARD! "Getting into Juilliard" has the

156.text:
same imposing ringtone as "How do you get
to Carnegie Hall?" In and of itself it is

162.text: a major achievement. But this commencement ceremony, this day of celebration is of course about

169.text:
having made it through Juilliard, after
striving, thriving, and finally surviving

177.text:
four years at this most demanding and prestigious
school of the performing arts. As someone

185.text:
who lived through that experience over 4 decades
ago, I salute and congratulate each and every

191.text:
one of you. Believe me when I say you already
have one big thing on your resume. Now I'm

199.text:
told that the Drama Division is a kinder,
gentler place than it was under the formidable

203.text:
John Houseman back in the 70s, where twice
a year after working on a production of Shakespeare,

210.text:
Shaw, or Chekov we, as a class, would be made
to sit in a long row while each member of

216.text:
the drama faculty was given an opportunity
to "critique" us individually. My critique

223.text:
invariably centered on my need to relax. My
tongue, which I was made to look at in a magnifying

231.text: mirror, unfortunately had a deep groove. My S's were sibilant, my voice was nasal, my

238.text: jaw was locked, and my neck stiff, my shoulders chronically tense, my diaphragm not functioning

243.text: properly. Also I had a pelvic thrust and fallen arches. But above all...I NEEDED TO RELAX.

254.text:
Well, thank you very much, but... How was
one to relax when subjected to a full body

262.text: CT scan every day with the test results publicly discussed twice a year?! Indeed, how to let

272.text: our natural talent flow and trust our instincts while being made to feel totally self-conscious:

280.text:
that has always been the dilemma for us Juilliard
students, and I sympathize with and applaud

286.text:
every student who has endured those daily
prognoses. However... That said, looking back

293.text:
after 4 decades I find the memory of those
ominous critiques to be wildly amusing, and

301.text: for what it's worth, I still need to relax. Even as I am speaking to you now, my shoulders

306.text:
are tense, my jaw's a bit locked, and I gave
up on my tongue years ago. As daunting, as

315.text:
competitive, repetitive, and humbling it all
was, I can honestly say those were the most

322.text:
exhilarating years of my life! To finally
have a breakthrough or receive high praise

329.text:
from a revered teacher -- there was no greater
euphoria. AND my God, even the morning elevator

336.text:
rides were, in more ways than one, an uplifting
experience! Rubbing elbows with musical prodigies,

345.text:
opera singers, famous faculty members, those
flocks of exquisite young women in pink tights

350.text:
who shared our 3rd floor rehearsal spaces.
I still can't believe it, but I actually

356.text:
rode up on occasion with George Balanchine,
Jerome Robins, Martha Graham and once (be

365.text:
still my heart) with Maria Callas, who was
giving her master class.

370.text:
Aspirational oxygen: it's the air we breathe
at Juilliard. And being just across the

378.text:
street from those grand theaters where, on
any given night, world class conductors, musicians,

385.text:
singers, dancers, actors are performing -- you
can't help but feel you're part of an awe-inspiring

392.text:
and lasting tradition. You know, there were
no dorms back in the 70's, absolutely no campus

401.text:
life -- in other words, no way to meet guys.
I remember exiting the building one evening

410.text:
and being approached by a really handsome
young man, a conducting student, who said

416.text:
he had an extra ticket to the NY Philharmonic
playing Brahms. Well...I didn't give a fig

422.text:
about Brahms but it seemed like a chance to
date a hot guy. We sat in the orchestra and

437.text:
shortly after the music began I became aware
of his heavy breathing, moaning and body twitching.

447.text:
I looked up, his eyes were tightly closed
and I realized his rapture had nothing to

452.text:
do with his proximity to me. When the music
stopped he gushed "I have never heard the

459.text:
first movement played more brilliantly!" "I
know," I whispered breathlessly, feeling like I'd

465.text:
faked an orgasm. I had no idea you could get
that excited about the first movement!

488.text: Maybe the second, but not the first! Well, alas,

494.text:
we had only one more date after that...considerably
more low brow in nature. But I made subsequent

504.text:
dates after that at the Philharmonic. Buying
inexpensive tickets I had cheap dates with

511.text:
Arthur Rubinstein, with Vladimir Horowitz
appearing as soloists. I often stood outside the

518.text:
Metropolitan Opera many evenings after school
ended hoping for a free ticket...I bought

524.text:
standing room and balcony seats to the opera
and ballet. So much of my Juilliard experience

531.text:
was tied to the thrill of simply crossing
the street and seeing great performers. The

538.text:
reason I spoke of being "giddy with delight"
to be here today is because this is the first

542.text:
formal ceremony I have ever attended at the
school. After completing my first year in

548.text:
1970, I was awarded a $1,000 scholarship that
was given to a hard-working, economically

553.text:
needy student. Unfortunately, I didn't realize
I had to show up and receive it at that year's

558.text:
commencement -- I just thought the check was
in the mail! So I was M.I.A. Then, alas, in 1974,

569.text:
I didn't attend my own graduation because
I was already employed as an apprentice at

574.text:
the Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, CT.
So I never collected my diploma. Then about

581.text:
15 years ago, President Polisi very graciously
decided to surprise me and award me my actual

588.text:
diploma after all those years at an alumni
event in L.A. Alas, as he was making his surprise

596.text:
presentation after lunch, I unwittingly  was
in the ladies' room -- M.I.A. again! So thank

608.text:
you, Joseph, for not giving up on me! I'm not
only honored to be here, I'm also relieved

614.text:
that I finally showed up! You know, I've been
talking to you all in my head for many weeks

622.text:
now -- wondering what perspective to share,
having preceded you into the professional

627.text:
world by 4 decades. Is there a quintessential
observation regarding this life we share in

636.text:
the performing arts? And that story about
finally showing up kept coming back to me.

643.text:
Because, of course, that is simply, essentially
what our life is. It is all about showing

651.text:
up. That is our passion, our task, our responsibility,
our privilege. Our presence, with a capital

661.text:
P, is required. We show up on time because
that is the first measure of our professionalism.

670.text:
We show up in good health because stamina
and mental clarity are the sine qua non of

676.text:
a performing career. We show up prepared for
the work at hand or we waste our colleague's

682.text:
time or an audience's money. We show up -- when
we are underslept or our bodies are aching,

690.text:
our hearts are breaking, or our personal life
is a distraction. And alas, more than ever

696.text:
these days, we must show up ready to have our
work process compromised by scheduling or

702.text: budgetary issues. There will be only one run-through with the full orchestra, or soloist.

709.text:
There will be fewer previews, less rehearsal
time. The script will be late, lines must

714.text:
be memorized overnight. We now must work on
dangerous sets, sing when jet lagged, dance

721.text:
when injured, act in a close-up well past
our 14th hour on a film set. This brings me

728.text:
to my favorite line in all of Shakespeare,
spoken by Hamlet, when he says, "The readiness

733.text:
is all". Indeed, in our work, the readiness
is all. We must show up time and again In readiness

744.text:
to walk on that high wire, and often under
very difficult circumstances. But if this

750.text:
high wire is the most terrifying and challenging
aspect of our lives as performers, the most

758.text:
glorious aspect is this: on cue, on point,
on the downbeat, or on "Action!"

767.text:
We get to show up in the fullness of our being,
and present not just our talent and technique,

776.text:
but the depth of our character, the force
of our personality, the breadth of our life

782.text:
experience -- our point of view. This is worthy
of a lifetime of discipline and exploration

790.text:
-- to refine that Presence with a capital
P. What's more -- our vulnerability, our human

799.text:
frailty, even our failings and darkness, can
be our greatest gift as artists. Since I've

807.text:
quoted Shakespeare, there's nowhere to go
but Kanye West, who sang "Damn! ...Everything

819.text:
I'm NOT made me everything I am." Happily,
dear graduates, you've chosen a very secure

827.text:
profession. We cannot be replaced by a computer
or an automated voice. Be outsourced to Mexico

837.text:
or China or made into an app. In this hyper-kinetic
age of information and technological advances,

844.text:
we living, breathing artists get to show up
and invite people to experience in our presence

852.text:
the beauty, the complexity of the human condition
through language, music, and movement. I

859.text:
believe our gifts are more important now than
ever. The playwright Tom Stoppard (who can

865.text:
easily out-verbalize Kanye) wrote: "We
get our moral sensibility from art. When we

873.text:
have a purely technological society, it will
be time for mass suicide."

879.text:
Well, that's a fairly dark assessment, but without
a doubt we are living in a transformative,

887.text:
convulsive time in history. We are overwhelmed,
not just by technology, but by a hyper sense

894.text:
of consciousness on issues of race, gender,
religion, and politics, which seem to divide

900.text:
people more than ever. Surely the work we
do can have an enlightening, humanizing effect...at

911.text:
best a hopeful and healing one. So, my fellow
alums, it is something of a spiritual mission

921.text:
that we keep showing up. I urge you to have
faith in time -- good work, great work requires

937.text:
time. Take your greatest joy from the daily
practice of your work. Ours is a collaborative

946.text:
art. So turn off your phones and get to know
your colleagues. Even if you're playing

955.text:
Mame, you need a chorus of adoring young men
to sing to you and keep lifting you in the

962.text:
air. Believe me, it helps if they like
you. And try not to think of your youth as

971.text:
a commodity to be cashed in or of age as a
liability. I would encourage you to carefully

980.text:
read the biographies of the esteemed honorees
here onstage with me today. They kept showing

988.text: up and doing their work, often brilliant work, every day and...FOR DECADES. If it's any

997.text:
comfort, I did not have my first big theatrical
success until my 30s, and did not start making

1004.text:
real money until my 40s. I turned 64 a few
weeks ago and I've never been busier. Furthermore

1012.text:
...when I grow up, I want to be Cicely Tyson!
Finally, before closing, I'd like to acknowledge

1034.text:
the families of the graduates who are here
today. Undoubtedly, you are so proud, happy,

1041.text:
relieved and well, perhaps, in debt. My mom
was widowed when I was 8 years old and, despite

1051.text:
my having almost a full scholarship, she had
to make great sacrifices to pay for my housing

1057.text:
and living expenses. So whether from Buffalo
or Beijing, I know similar sacrifices have

1063.text:
been made and the parents here should be acknowledged
and thanked as deeply as the faculty and administration.

1094.text:
One of my most poignant memories was my mother
waiting for me in the lobby of what was then

1101.text:
called Philharmonic Hall in the summer of
1970 -- I had to reaudition for the speech

1107.text:
faculty after doing some corrective work on
my sibilant "S." I remember racing from the

1114.text:
third floor office of John Houseman to tell
her the Awesome news: that I got into Juilliard!

1122.text:
We then went to the Algonquin Hotel on 44th
Street and had 2 Southern Comfort Manhattans

1127.text:
straight up with a cherry EACH. It was the
only time I got drunk with my mother. So this

1137.text:
evening at 7pm I am taking my family and
a few friends back to the Algonquin Hotel

1144.text:
...46 years later. I shall first drink a toast
to Virginia Baranski, who would have been gobsmacked

1155.text:
that her daughter became a doctor.
Next I'll drink a toast in gratitude to Juilliard,

1164.text:
and all my extraordinary teachers, many
of whom became lifelong friends. And last,

1171.text:
but not least, I shall drink a toast to the
graduating class of 2016. May you show up

1180.text:
and make your Presence felt as artists in
the world for many decades to come! Congratulations

1187.text:
for getting into -- and getting out of -- Juilliard!
Bravissimi! See you out there.
